---
layout: post
title: Pose Estimation
tags:  deep-learning post-estimation
---

![](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Djamila_Aouada/publication/317380302/figure/fig4/AS:502548211527680@1496828238063/Generated-meshes-using-SMPL-14-Left-ground-truth-right-example-of-input-top-and.png)

Human pose estimation is the task of computing the 2D (find the 2D pixel location of each joint for each person in an image) or 3D (find 3D joint distances relative to the center of the person, usually limited to constrained environments such as motion capture rooms) pose from a RGB or RGBD image.

This is often done using the Skined Multi-Person Linear Model (SMPL) parametric human mesh model. This model represents most human shapes using only 82 parameters that control 6890 vertices.

# [Learning to Estimate 3D Human Pose and Shape from a Single Color Image](https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.04092)

![](http://www.europe.naverlabs.com/var/siteaccesses/storage/images/media/public-media/images/figure-1/1797857-1-eng-GB/figure-1_extralarge.png)

The proposed method decomposes the 3D pose estimation from 2D images as two steps (networks): compute the 2D pose (silhouettes and keypoints heatmaps) from the 2D images and compute the SMPL from the 2D pose.

By applying these two networks consecutively, the loss checks that the projection of the silhouette and the keypoints match the annotation of keypoints and silhouettes in the training data and also the projection of SMPL onto the 2D pose.

# [End-to-end Recovery of Human Shape and Pose](http://files.is.tue.mpg.de/black/papers/kanazawaCVPR2018.pdf)

![](https://akanazawa.github.io/hmr/resources/images/overview.png)

To address the lack of large-scale ground truth 3D annotation for in-the-wild images, is to take advantage of these unpaired 2D keypoint annotations and 3D scans in a conditional generative adversarial manner. ResNet 50 is used as the backbone.

The idea is that, given an image, the network has to infer the 3D mesh parameters and the camera such that the 3D keypoints match the annotated 2D keypoints after projection. To deal with ambiguities, these parameters are sent to a discriminator network, whose task is to determine if the 3D parameters correspond to bodies of real humans or not. Hence the network is encouraged to output parameters on the human manifold and the discriminator acts as a weak supervision. The network implicitly learns the angle limits for each joint and is discouraged from making people with unusual body shapes.

# [DensePose: Dense Human Pose Estimation In The Wild](https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.00434)

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/544269/35792510-e3646410-0a90-11e8-8390-5b3a11b800bf.png)

DensePost modifies MaskRCNN to also regress the corresponding coordinates of the mesh surface for each pixel. To this end, ground-truth includes sparse correspondence annotations between people in images and points on the mesh surface for 50k humans from the MS-Coco dataset.

# [Stacked hourglass net-works for human pose estimation](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1603.06937.pdf)

![](https://media.springernature.com/original/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-319-46484-8_29/MediaObjects/419983_1_En_29_Fig3_HTML.gif)

Hourglass network (similar to U-net) is a type of convolution neural network which uses pooling to reduce the feature to very low dimension (4x4) and then use upsampling to upscale the feature to higher dimension. Feature from previous layer is added to the input via skip connections.

# [Learning Monocular 3D Human Pose Estimation from Multi-view Images](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1803.04775)

![](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/WYeo7QdWLHs/maxresdefault.jpg)

This paper addresses the problem of insufficient labeled training data for 3D human pose estimation for multi-view. The proposes method assumes that the 3D pose for human in different views should be identical subject to some rigid transform (i.e., translation and rotation). Accordingly, a network can be learned by combining a small set of labeled data and many unlabled data, which can be used for inferring on a monocular image.

# [Ordinal Depth Supervision for 3D Human Pose Estimation](http://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_cvpr_2018/papers/Pavlakos_Ordinal_Depth_Supervision_CVPR_2018_paper.pdf)

![](https://www.seas.upenn.edu/~pavlakos/projects/ordinal/files/ordinal-teaser.png)

This paper addresses the limitation of 3D pose annotation data by using a weaker label, which is the pairwise ranking of depth of joints.

# [BodyNet: Volumetric Inference of 3D Human Body Shapes](https://www.di.ens.fr/willow/research/bodynet/)

![](https://media.springernature.com/original/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-030-01234-2_2/MediaObjects/474212_1_En_2_Fig2_HTML.gif)

BodyNet proposes a voxel representation for 3D human pose instead of SMPL. The voxel representation defines a 3D voxel grid center at root join of human, the occupied grid takes value 1 otherwise 0. A neural network is learned end-to-end to compute this representation from a 2d image, based on 3D voxel loss, 2D reprojection loss and euclidean distance to ground truth representation.

# [Self-supervised Learning of Motion Capture](https://sites.google.com/view/selfsupervisedlearningofmotion/)

![](https://ai2-s2-public.s3.amazonaws.com/figures/2017-08-08/cf2ab0e639c19877596036603a3000ce7a1deb35/2-Figure1-1.png)

The propose network predicts the body parameters for the SMPL 3D human mesh model [25]. Neural networks weights are pretrained using synthetic data and finetuned using self-supervised losses driven by differentiable keypoint, segmentation, and motion reprojection errors, against detected 2D keypoints, 2D segmentation and 2D optical flow, respectively. 

# [Total Capture: A 3D Deformation Model for Tracking Faces, Hands, and Bodies](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1801.01615)

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

Total captures address the problems of 3D pose estimation for body, face and fingers in markless set up. Their input is multi-view images. The final model is an union of the model for body, face and fingers.
